what: Avian functional responses to landscape recovery
title: Avian Response to Recovering Landscapes
text: Citation: Ikin, Karen et al. (2019), Data : Avian functional responses landscape recovery, Dryad, Dataset, https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.d6k0804 data set retrieved DRYAD public domain, released Charles Darwin University, McGill University, James Cook University. aim database measure effect restoring vegetation across 17 sites Australia. data set also includes ecological traits birds, attributes restored sites.

title: Avian Response to Recovering Landscapes
text: searching DRYAD explanation dataset, found supplementary material published article Journal Royal Society Publishing. first two data files imported directly DRYAD. files DRYAD abbreviated species names, combined supplemental material recreate table. column names bird data reference different species local Australia. IDs reference multiple measurements multiple sites. SiteData.txt information various sites, including geographic location.
code: BirdData_full <- read.delim("../data-raw/Ikin_2019_BirdData.txt") SiteData_full <- read.delim("../data-raw/Ikin_2019_SiteData.txt")  head(colnames(BirdData_full)) ## [1] "id"    "amag"  "apos"  "arav"  "bb"    "bbowl" species <- read.csv("../data-raw/SPECIES-GENUS.csv") new_names <- c("id") append(x = new_names,species$Species,1) -> new_names colnames(BirdData_full) <- c(new_names)  BirdSite_Data <- full_join(BirdData_full, SiteData_full, by ="id") apply(X = BirdSite_Data[2:122], MARGIN = 2, sum) -> small_table # BirdSite_Data <- full_join(BirdData_full, SiteData_full, by ="id") head(BirdSite_Data[122:130]) ##   Yellow-tailed Black-Cockatoo Yellow-tufted Honeyeater year    growth   site ## 1                            0                        0 2002 oldgrowth ARCH-1 ## 2                            0                        0 2002  regrowth ARCH-2 ## 3                            0                        0 2002  regrowth ARCH-3 ## 4                            0                        0 2002  regrowth ARCH-4 ## 5                            0                        0 2002  planting BELL-1 ## 6                            0                        0 2002 oldgrowth BELL-2 ##   farm     land     long       lat ## 1 Arch Gundagai 148.0782 -35.13095 ## 2 Arch Gundagai 148.1011 -35.16487 ## 3 Arch Gundagai 148.0843 -35.16774 ## 4 Arch Gundagai 148.0770 -35.17336 ## 5 Bell Tarcutta 147.6615 -35.30462 ## 6 Bell Tarcutta 147.6592 -35.30638

title: Avian Response to Recovering Landscapes
text: heatmap sites measured. sites southern region New South Wales, state currently deforesting portions Nagmadi National Forest Canberra. dataset considering family birds NSW, relevant see deforesting can affect native species populations. SiteData.txt file also includes background physical state farm (Planting / Regrowing / Growth), well tree coverage. important vectors consider effect species.

title: Avian Response to Recovering Landscapes
text: can see dot plots, greater concentration species sites significant regrowth occurred.
code: BirdSite_Data %>%    filter(ln_cover != 0) -> BirdSite_Data   ggplot(data=BirdSite_Data, mapping = aes(x = farm, y = site.rich, color = growth)) +   geom_point(size = 2.25) +   geom_smooth(method = lm) +   xlab(label = "Active Sites in New South Wales") +   ylab(label = "Total count per Visit") ## `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x' ggplot(data=BirdSite_Data, mapping = aes(x = ln_cover, y = site.rich, color = growth)) +   geom_point() +   geom_smooth(method = loess) +   xlab(label = "Ln of tree coverage per site") +   ylab(label = "Total count per visit") ## `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Avian Response to Recovering Landscapes
text: Looking interconnectivity species present across NSW help us better understand ecological variety. OpenTree taxonomic package allow us sort species scientific name combined taxon tree. author included supplementary data table original article. dataset, reducing number species table just genuses counts greater 150.
code: small_table <- data.frame((small_table))  colnames(small_table)[1] <- "Count" small_table$Species <- c(species$Species[1:121]) small_table %>%    filter(Count >= 150) -> smaller_table  left_join(smaller_table,species, by = "Species") -> bird_list  bird_taxa <- tnrs_match_names(bird_list$Scientific.name)  bird_tr <- tol_induced_subtree(ott_ids = bird_taxa$ott_id) ##  Progress [---------------------------------] 0/213 (  0) ?s Progress [==============================] 213/213 (100)  0s plot(bird_tr,cex = 3)

what: Transcriptomic analysis of bleached Orbicella Faveolata
title: Orbicella Coral Fasta import
text: Due increasing ocean temperature, species coral experiencing higher higher levels bleaching. algal symbionts live coral known leave temperatures persist even degrees higher normal water temperature. Bleaching isn’t always permanent, however, brief amount time algae can come back restore life coral. know true, still know specifically mediates survival rates coral. analyzing full transcriptome coral symbiont, hope better comprehend genes responsible difference.

title: Orbicella Coral Fasta import
text: Pinzón, Jorge H. et al. (2015), Data : Whole transcriptome analysis..bleaching reef-building coral, Dryad, Dataset, https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.fj276 data set retrieved DRYAD public domain, released University Texas Arlington, Pennsylvania State University.

title: Orbicella Coral Fasta import
text: FASTA files already collected, next step compare reads (sequences along transcriptome) full genome. compare full genome, need reference. NCBI, Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute created full representation Orbicella faveolata genome. “https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/assembly/GCF_002042975.1/” 2017: 30,162 32,574 sequences mapped genes psuedogenes.

title: Orbicella Coral Fasta import
text: Note: Due difficulties large dataset, data processes removed/commented . Specifically, alignment featurecount processes. rely Rsubread map reference genome samples. First, build index based reference genome. purpose generating index compare fasta reads .
code: library(Rsubread)  index = "GCF_002042975.1_ofav_dov_v1_genomic.fna" ## buildindex(basename = "my_index", reference = index)  treated_fasta <- "ESM2_Bleaching_Metatranscriptome_transcriptome.fasta" wild_fasta <- "ESM3_Bleaching_O-faveolata_transcriptome.fasta"   ## align(index = "my_index", readfile1=treated_fasta, output_file = "treatedResults.bam")

title: Orbicella Coral Fasta import
text: understand genome better, add annotation includes Gene Id general purpose. Mapping suggests something wrong index. enough genes mapped properly. great start!
code: ann <- "genomic.gtf"  ## treatment_Count <- featureCounts("treatedResults.bam", annot.ext = ann, isGTFAnnotationFile = TRUE)
